document.docTitle: Additions to the trigonalyid (Hymenoptera: Trigonalyidae) fauna of India with the description of a new species from south India

emphasis.docTitle: Additions to the trigonalyid ( Hymenoptera : Trigonalyidae ) fauna of India with the description of a new species from south India

subSection.paragraph: EZHUTHUPALLICKAL BENNY FEMI 1,2* , AVUNJIKKATTU PARAMBIL RANJITH 1,3 & DHARMA RAJAN PRIYADARSANAN 1,4

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Ashoka Trust for Research in Ecology and the Environment (ATREE), Royal Enclave, Srirampura, Jakkur Post, Bangalore 560064, India .

subSection.paragraph:
A new species of
Taeniogonalos
is described and illustrated from Western Ghats, Kerala , India . The male of
Taeniogonalos eurysoma Chen & van Achterberg, 2020
is described for the first time along with its first distribution record from India . The new species and
T. eurysoma
are illustrated along with a distribution map of Indian
Taeniogonalos
.

Key words:
India
, male description , new distribution record , taxonomy , Western Ghats

Trigonalyidae ( Hymenoptera ) is a globally distributed small family of rarely collected wasps belonging to the superfamily, Trigonalyiodea, encompassing some 123 species (
Aguiar et al . 2013
;
Binoy et al . 2022
; Kumar & Hegde 2023 ). Most species thrive in tropical and subtropical regions, with only one species documented in Europe and a complete absence observed in arctic and alpine habitats ( Carmean & Kimsey 1998 ). Based on morphological phylogenetic analysis there are two recognised subfamilies of Trigonalyidae viz., Orthogonalyinae and Trigonalyinae ( Carmean & Kimsey 1998 ).

The genus
Taeniogonalos
( Fig. 5 ) belongs to the subfamily Trigonalyinae .
Taeniogonalos
is a widely distributed genus, occurring in Afrotropical, Oriental, Eastern Palaearctic, Nearctic, Australian and Neotropical Regions ( Carmean & Kimsey 1998 ). A total of six
Taeniogonalos species
are reported from India and 20 from China (
Chen et al . 2014
, 2020 ). The Indian fauna of
Taeniogonalos
was revised and fully illustrated by
Binoy et al. (2022)
. We describe and illustrate a new species of the genus from Kerala , India as well as the first report of the species along with the first male description of
T. eurysoma Chen & van Achterberg, 2020
from India .

The specimens included in the present study were collected by hand and via Malaise trapping from Karnataka and Arunachal Pradesh ( Fig. 6 ). Specimens were treated with hexamethyldisilazane ( Heraty & Hawks 1998 ) and later dried and pinned. Images were taken with a Keyence VHX-6000 digital microscope and Olympus OM-D with 60 mm lens. The distribution map was made using QGIS 3.30. Morphological terminology is adapted from
Chen et al . (2014)
. Cuticular sculpture terminology follows Harris (1979).

Type specimens are deposited in the collections of the ATREE Insect Museum, Bangalore, India ( AIMB ) and the holotype will be subsequently transferred to the National Zoological Collections’ of the Zoological Survey of India , Western Ghat Regional Centre, Kozhikode (ZSIK).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Taeniogonalos Schulz, 1906: 212
. Type species (by monotypy):
Trigonalys maculata Smith, 1851
. See
Binoy et al . (2022)
for complete synonymy.

Diagnosis. Antennae filiform with 21–26 antennomeres. Male flagellomeres 8 th –16 th with linear tyloids. Supra-antennal elevation reduced and far separated. Fore wing often with subapical dark patch. Second metasomal sternite simple, expanded, often with armature. Third sternite without projection or armature.
Distribution. Afrotropical, Oriental, East Palaearctic, Nearctic, Australian and Neotropical regions.
( Figs 1–2 , 5A )

Type material .
Holotype female, India : Karnataka , Belgaum , Nipani , 16°2412 N, 74°2242 E,
615 m
.
a.s.l.,
2.vii.2020
, coll. Deepak Deshpande ( AIMB ).
Description. Holotype , female, length of body 7.7 mm ; fore wing 6.0 mm.

Wings . Fore wing with length of vein 1-M 1.4 × as long as vein 1-SR, vein 1-M curved and vein 1-SR straight; subdiscal and discal cells setose ( Fig. 2E ); second submarginal cell sessile anteriorly, 1.4 × as long as third cell, connecting with discal cell at a transverse point.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1 .
Taeniogonalos deepaki Femi & Ranjith
sp. nov.
, holotype, female A) habitus, lateral view; B) head, anterior view; C) head, dorsal view; D) head, lateral view; E) mesosoma, lateral view; F) mesosoma, dorsal view.

FIGURE 2 .
Taeniogonalos deepaki Femi & Ranjith
sp. nov.
, holotype, female A) propodeum, dorsal view; B) metasoma, dorsal view; C) metasoma, lateral view; D) metasoma, ventral view; E) wings.

subSubSection.paragraph: Colour. Head, mesosoma and metasoma predominantly tricoloured (black to brownish black, red to reddish brown, and yellow). Body mostly reddish brown mandible except apex, clypeus, frons near toruli, inner eye margin, anterior to median ocellus, lateral to posterior ocelli, temple anteriorly, occiput posteriorly, pronotum anterodorsally and antero-laterally, postero-laterally, middle lobe of mesoscutum anterolaterally, scutellum except medially, metanotum, propodeum submedially, mesopleuron postero-laterally, fore coxa, fore trochanter, fore femur basally, mid coxa apical two third, mid trochanter, mid femur basally, hind coxa dorsally, hind trochanter, hind femur basally, hind tibia basally, tegula, first metasomal tergite postero-medially, second metasomal tergite antero- medially, metasomal tergites four to six except medially, metasomal sternites one and two posterior one third, metasomal tergite three postero-laterally yellow. Apex of mandibles, posterior margin of clypeus, face antero-medially, frons medially, ocelli, malar area, propleuron, pronotum medio-posteriorly, occiput dorso-ventrally, mesopleuron anteriorly and posterior half, metapleuron posterior half, hind coxa ventrally, metanotum posteriorly, propodeum antero-medially and postero-medially, first metasomal tergite except medio-posteriorly, second metasomal tergite anterior half except antero-medially, third metasomal tergite anterior one third and posteriorly, fourth metasomal tergite posteriorly, fifth metasomal tergite antero-laterally and medially, metasomal sternite one except posterior margin, second metasomal sternite anterior half, third metasomal sternite except postero-laterally, metasomal sternites 4+ black. Metasomal tergites and sternites 2+ with white setae.
Biology . Unknown
Etymology. The species is named after Dr Deepak Deshpande, a medical doctor and a nature enthusiast who collected the specimen.
Distribution. India ( Karnataka ).

Remarks.
Taeniogonalos deepaki
sp. nov.
resembles
T. thwaitesii (Westwood, 1874)
from Sri Lanka , in having head, mesosoma and metasoma predominantly tricoloured and the second submarginal cell of fore wing sessile anteriorly and connecting with the discal cell as a transverse point. However the new species differs from
T. thwaitesii
in having the yellow band of second tergite not broad centrally but forming a conical projection laterally ( vs broad centrally in
T. thwaitesii
); mesopleuron without four distinct yellow spots ( vs mesopleuron with four distinct yellow spots in
T. thwaitesii
); scutellum largely yellow and reddish brown medially ( vs largely brown with narrow yellow bands laterally in
T. thwaitesii
). Additionally,
T. deepaki
sp. nov.
resembles
T. gestroi (Schulz, 1908)
from India and China , in having posterior half of first submarginal cells of fore wing more or less darkened. However,
T. deepaki
sp. nov.
differs from
T. gestroi
in having general body colouration reddish brown ( vs black in
T. gestroi
) mesopleuron and metapleuron without extensive yellow pattern ( vs with extensive yellow pattern in
T. gestroi
); metasomal tergite one with continuous yellow margin posteriorly ( vs a medial yellow spot in
T. gestroi
) and v shaped yellow mark behind stemmaticum absent ( vs present in
T. gestroi
)

bibRefCitation.author: Chen, H. Y. & Hong, C. D. & van Achterberg, C. & Pang, H.
bibRefCitation.refString: Chen, H. Y., Hong, C. D., van Achterberg, C. & Pang, H. (2020) New species and new records of Trigonalyidae (Hymenoptera) from Tibet, China. ZooKeys, 918, 83 - 98. https: // doi. org / 10.3897 / zookeys. 918.49729

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined.
Male , India : Arunachal Pradesh , Yemsing , 28°7'39.72" N and 94°57'50.8" E
1259 m
.a.s.l.,
28.iv.2022
, coll. A.P. Ranjith ( AIMB )
.
Description. Male. length of body 6.75 mm ; fore wing 6.1 mm .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3 .
Taeniogonalos eurysoma Chen & van Achterberg, 2020
, male A) habitus, lateral view; B) head, anterior view; C) head, antero-ventral view; D) head, dorsal view; E) mesosoma, lateral view; F) mesosoma, dorsal view.

FIGURE 4 .
Taeniogonalos eurysoma Chen & van Achterberg, 2020
, male A) tyloids; B) propodeum, dorsal view; C) metasoma, dorsal view; D) metasoma, ventral view; E) apical metasomal segments, dorsal view; F) fore wing.

subSubSection.paragraph: Wings . Fore wing with length of vein 1-M 1.3 × as long as vein 1-SR, vein 1-M curved and vein 1-SR straight; subdiscal and discal cells less setose ( Fig. 4F ); second submarginal cell sessile anteriorly, 1.4 × as long as third cell, connecting with discal cell by forming a vertical vein.

Colour. Same as female except mandibles largely yellow with apical black margin, posterior margin of tergites, 1st and 2nd sternites with yellow stripes; yellow spot on the postero-lateral margin of mesoscutum and a more or less continuous ivory band on metanotum.
Biology . Unknown
Distribution. India ( Arunachal Pradesh ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5 . Field images of
Taeniogonalos species A
)
Taeniogonalos deepaki Femi & Ranjith
sp. nov.
; B) unidentified
Taeniogonalos species.

subSection.paragraph:
According to the key provided in
Binoy et al . (2022)
,
T. eurysoma
is found to be a remarkable addition to the Indian
Taeniogonalos
fauna based on the entirely black scutellum. The only species reported with unicoloured (yellow to orange or yellow) scutellum is
T. fulvoscutellata (Ayyar)
from India . Sexual dimorphism is not very pronounced in
T. eurysoma
other than, mandibles yellow except apical margin (black in female); mesoscutum coarsely rugose punctate (coarsely sculptured in female), yellow spot on the postero-lateral margin (absent in female); ivory band of metanotum continuous (discontinuous and less setose in female); 1st and 2nd sternites with yellow stripes (ivory in female); first metasomal tergite 1.1 × as wide as long (0.4 × as long as apically wide in female), black spot in the middle of yellow posterior band of second tergite narrow (very wide in female); fore wing with length of vein 1-M 1.3 × as long as vein 1-SR (1.1 × in female), second submarginal cell 1.4 × as long as third cell (1.3 × in female).

Most species of
Taeniogonalos
have been described from south India particularly from the states of Kerala and Tamil Nadu (
Binoy et al . 2022
; Kumar & Hegde 2023 ), including the possible occurrence of
T. thwaitesii ( Smith & Tripotin 2015 )
. Only two species are reported from Northeast India so far (
T. eurysoma
and
T. kerala
). However, more extensive taxonomic studies might yield more species from Northeast India in the future. The occurrence of the male of
T. eurysoma
from Arunachal Pradesh points towards a possible overlap of the
Taeniogonalos
fauna between China and India . The Chinese fauna is quite speciose with 20 extant species (
Chen et al , 2014
, 2020 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 6 . Distribution map of Indian
Taeniogonalos species.

subSection.paragraph: We thank Dr Deepak Deshpande for donating the specimen as well as for the field images. EBF is grateful to the University Grants Commission for the financial assistance. APR & PDR acknowledge Global Conservation, USA for the financial assistance for Siang Expedition 2023, and the Department of Biotechnology, Government of India , for the lab infrastructure through a major research project on "Bio-resource and Sustainable livelihoods in North East India (BT/01/17/NE/TAX). APR is thankful to ATREE and Bawa Family Fund for support.
